title: Kremlin aide warns West over seizure of Russian vessels
description: Russia could deploy its navy to prevent European powers from seizing its vessels and may retaliate against European shipping if Russian ships are taken,
fullText:
MOSCOW, Feb 17 (Reuters) - Russia could deploy its navy to prevent European powers from seizing its vessels and may retaliate against European shipping if Russian ‚Äåships are taken, Nikolai Patrushev, one of Russia's leading hardliners, was quoted as ‚Äåsaying on Tuesday.

Western states have sought to cripple Russia's economy with sanctions and in recent months have tried to block ‚Äãoil tankers suspected of involvement in Russian oil shipments. In January, the United States seized a Russian-flagged oil tanker as part of efforts to curb Venezuelan oil exports.

Patrushev, a Kremlin aide who is a close ally of President Vladimir Putin, said Russia needed to give a tough response - particularly ‚Äåtowards Britain, France and Baltic ‚Å†states.

"If we don't give them a tough rebuff, then soon the British, French and even the Balts (Baltic nations) will become arrogant to such an extent ‚Å†that they will try to block our country's access to the seas at least in the Atlantic basin," Patrushev, who serves as chairman of Russia's Maritime Board, told the Russian media outlet Argumenty i ‚ÄãFakty.

"In ‚Äãthe main maritime areas, including regions far from Russia, ‚Äãsubstantial forces must be permanently deployed - ‚Äåforces capable of cooling the ardour of Western pirates," he said.

Patrushev said that the navies of major powers were undergoing radical technological change and modernisation amid what he said was clear "gunboat diplomacy" from Washington over Venezuela and Iran. Russia's updated naval shipbuilding programme to 2050 will be submitted for approval soon, he said.

He also said that Russia believed the NATO military alliance planned ‚Äåto blockade the Russian exclave of Kaliningrad on the ‚ÄãBaltic Sea.

"Any attempt at a naval blockade of our ‚Äãcountry is completely illegal from the standpoint ‚Äãof international law, and the concept of a 'shadow fleet', which EU representatives ‚Äåbrandish at every turn, is a legal ‚Äãfiction," he said.

The shadow ‚Äãfleet refers to a network of vessels that Western nations say are operated by Russia to evade sanctions.

"By implementing their naval blockade plans, the Europeans are deliberately pursuing a ‚Äãscenario of military escalation, testing ‚Äåthe limits of our patience and provoking active retaliatory measures," Patrushev said. "If a peaceful ‚Äãresolution to this situation fails, the blockade will be broken and eliminated by ‚Äãthe navy."

title: A Ukrainian drone pilot found a hidden Russian arsenal, only to discover it was filled with horses and old cars
description: Cosmos, a fiber-optic drone pilot, told Business Insider he was hunting for hidden Russian storages when he found the Ladas and two horses.
fullText:
A Ukrainian drone pilot told Business Insider of how he found a Russian arsenal of horses and Ladas.

Russia has increasingly been seen using unconventional transport, such as horses or bicycles.

The pilot's commander said it's a sign of how Russia fights and calculates its losses differently.

Cosmos floated his quadcopter over the ruined warehouse, guiding it through a corner of the roof where shattered metal sheets had collapsed to form a hole.

The drone pilot's unit, the Wild Division, suspected that the building was a logistics hub for Russian soldiers, roughly 15 km, or about 9 miles, from the line of contact in southern Ukraine. These hidden locations often held ordnance or fuel stockpiles, and Cosmos' fiber-optic drone was armed with explosives to destroy them.

Yet inside, the drone rotated its camera to reveal what looked more like a farmer's garage: Four civilian cars, a pair of motorcycles, and two bridled horses.

"We had not expected to see this. It was unusual," Cosmos told Business Insider, speaking on condition that he be identified only by his call sign.

"We were expecting to find some armored vehicles," he added.

Video of the discovery went viral last week in Ukraine, as the war has increasingly seen Russian soldiers using unconventional transport tools, such as pack animals and bicycles, to conduct assaults or logistics missions. Cosmos said his drone mission was conducted in early February.

The smaller profile of a horse or civilian car might be harder for a drone to spot, though Russia's repeated use of them has also raised questions about the viability of its tactics and whether it's been producing enough military equipment to sustain its invasion.

Cosmos' squad mates and officers at the Wild Division, a first-person-view drone company in the 82nd Air Assault Brigade, had seen clips of Russian soldiers riding on horses to attack Ukrainian positions before.

One famous example they remember was in Zaporizhzhia, when a Ukrainian drone crew attacked Russian infantry crossing the front lines on horseback last month.

Cosmos, who's been piloting drones for a year, said it was the first time he'd personally seen the animals on the front lines.

He flew his explosive-laden drone straight into the back of one of the cars, and said his crew later struck several other vehicles inside. When Russian troops moved their transport assets, the Wild Division found the next warehouse and attacked that one, too, Cosmos said.

"The enemy usually lives in hiding close to these places," Cosmos said of the warehouse. "It's common for us to check all targets. Sometimes we can see the enemy infantry, or you can see their vehicles."

The Wild Division declined to say where exactly the warehouse was located, but its brigade is generally deployed in the Donbas.

The commander of Cosmos' battalion told Business Insider that the discovery of the horses surprised him, too.

"I thought it had been a location for transport vehicles, sort of a transfer hub," said the major, whose call sign is Fizruk.

Fizruk said the appearance of horses and cars in his area of the front line could be a sign that Russian forces are running low on standard resources, but also reflects Moscow's attritional nature of fighting.

The cars discovered by Cosmos appear to be Nivas, inexpensive civilian off-road vehicles from the Russian Lada car brand.

"They treat these like they will be losses anyway, that they will be destroyed anyway," he said. "Look, a Niva costs, let's say, $2,000. A Hummer, which the Armed Forces of Ukraine uses in many places, costs $20,000, maybe more."

"Since they lose their equipment in assaults, from that point of view, why pay $20,000 for one vehicle if you can buy 10 Nivas for $20,000?" Fizruk added.

The Kremlin is known to pressure the front line with repeated ground assaults, sending small groups of infantry to approach Ukrainian positions on foot or in cheap vehicles. The strategy has been costly, with NATO now saying that up to 25,000 Russian troops are dying each month.

Sustaining that style of war has pushed Moscow to informal means of recruitment and weapons procurement, including hiring troops from overseas and receiving ammunition from North Korea.

title: Denny Hamlin Admits He Is Also in the Wrong for Justin Allgaier Incident at Daytona 500
description: Justin Allgaier took 100% of the blame for the big wreck that happened during Lap 124 of the Daytona 500 on Sunday. Denny Hamlin, too, was involved in the incident and admitted graciously on Actions Detrimental that 20% of the blame belonged to him.
fullText:
Justin Allgaier took 100% of the blame for the big wreck that happened during Lap 124 of the Daytona 500 on Sunday. Denny Hamlin, too, was involved in the incident and admitted graciously on Actions Detrimental that 20% of the blame belonged to him. The wreck collected 20 drivers and changed the dynamics of the race altogether.

Allgaier was the race leader at the time of the wreck and Hamlin had been running behind him. There was just enough space for Hamlin to get by Allgaier and the veteran went for it with a push from behind. Just as he was about to pass, Allgaier pulled a late block and ended up turning both of them to the inside. Several cars behind them choked up as well.

Hamlin said on his podcast that what he made was definitely an aggressive move. But he also stood ground that he was going to take every opportunity he got to take the lead and that he had made up his mind 100 yards before actually making the move that he was going to do it. He also clarified that there would have been enough space for him on the outside had Allgaier not moved up.

He went on to explain, ‚ÄúMy 20% is that he didn‚Äôt have a whole lot of time for him to react or see that it was coming.‚Äù Now knowing what the outcome of his attempt is, there are things that Hamlin would have done differently.

‚ÄúWe were running 10 miles an hour faster than him at the time because of the push we got,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt would have caused a huge domino effect had I just checked up and not taken it. Or I could just gone to the bottom and probably cleared him doing it. All over again, had I known what the result was gonna be, I would have just stayed in line for a few more laps.‚Äù

Hamlin ended the race in an underwhelming 31st position. Allgaier ended up with a disappointing DNF in what was his second Daytona 500 start for JR Motorsports. He‚Äôd told the press after the race that he would have rather it be someone else‚Äôs fault than his own. But he did take up the responsbility completely and explain why he did what he did.

‚ÄúBut you can only do the things you know at 100%, and I did that and it didn‚Äôt work out,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI hate it for everyone else, right, but I‚Äôll stand here and take the blame square on my shoulders.‚Äù He will find a bit of ease knowing that Hamlin has taken a bit of the weight off him.

The post Denny Hamlin Admits He Is Also in the Wrong for Justin Allgaier Incident at Daytona 500 appeared first on The SportsRush.

title: Seth Greenberg takes shot at Kansas State Wildcats after Jerome Tang firing
description: College basketball analyst Seth Greenberg went off on the Kansas State Wildcats for how they handled the firing of head coach Jerome Tang.
fullText:
Seth Greenberg takes shot at Kansas State Wildcats after Jerome Tang firing appeared first on ClutchPoints. 

The Kansas State Wildcats‚Äô decision to fire basketball head coach Jerome Tang is garnering serious criticism from the likes of Seth Greenberg.

Kansas State made the decision to fire Tang after four seasons, having hired him in 2022. The athletics department stated they had¬†cause to fire the head coach¬†midseason, per ESPN‚Äôs college sports insider Pete Thamel.

‚ÄúKansas State is firing Jerome Tang for cause. They‚Äôve informed him of this formally tonight. The basis for the for cause firing is language in his contract that references any activity that brings ‚Äúpublic disrepute, embarrassment, ridicule‚Äù to Kansas State,‚Äù Thamel wrote.

Greenberg made a Feb. 17 appearance on ESPN‚Äôs SportsCenter. He called out the Wildcats‚Äô reasoning for letting go of Tang, citing it was the lack of wins that led to the firing, not for his actual conduct and behavior.

‚ÄúThe university said his behavior was embarrassing. To me, the university‚Äôs behavior is embarrassing. The athletic director‚Äôs behavior is embarrassing,‚Äù Greenberg said.

‚ÄúJerome Tang, he made mistakes. He made mistakes in his roster construction. He made mistakes in terms of how maybe he handled this team. But one thing he didn‚Äôt do, he didn‚Äôt deserve to be fired with cause; he‚Äôs getting fired because he did not win enough games.‚Äù

Seth Greenberg on Kansas State firing Jerome Tang for cause: ‚ÄúThe university said his behavior was embarrassing. To me, the university‚Äôs behavior is embarrassing. The athletic director‚Äôs behavior is embarrassing‚Ä¶ He didn‚Äôt deserve to be fired with cause‚Ä¶‚Äù pic.twitter.com/6FQvP3UVfI

‚Äî Awful Announcing (@awfulannouncing) February 16, 2026

Seth Greenberg is right to question Kansas State‚Äôs approach to its decision. Regardless, Jerome Tang will be looking for a new team next season.

Making the Elite Eight of the 2023 NCAA Tournament and the NIT the following year, Tang suffered back-to-back losing campaigns since. Throughout his four years with the Wildcats, he finished with a 71-57 overall record. This includes a 29-39 display throughout the team‚Äôs matchups in conference play.

Kansas State has a 10-15 overall record on the season, going 1-11 in its Big 12 matchups so far. They are close to the bottom of the Big 12 standings, having a tiebreaker advantage over the Utah Utes while trailing the Baylor Bears and the Colorado Buffaloes.

Going through six consecutive losses, the Wildcats will hope to return to the win column in their next matchup. They host the Bears as tip-off will take place on Feb. 17 at 9 p.m. ET.

title: Russian woman carries Ukraine placard at Winter Olympics opening ceremony
description: Anastasia Kucherova, a Russian living in Milan, voiced her opposition to Russia‚Äôs war against Ukraine with a highly symbolic, if anonymous, act: Carrying the Ukraine team placard during the opening ceremony of the Milan Cortina Winter Games.  Kucherova was swathed in a long, hooded silver puffer coat, her eyes covered with dark glasses ‚Äî like all the other placard bearers for the 92 nations competing in the Olympics.  The Ukraine sign was illuminated for the crowd to read.
fullText:
MILAN (AP) ‚Äî Anastasia Kucherova, a Russian living in Milan, voiced her opposition to Russia‚Äôs war against Ukraine with a highly symbolic, if anonymous, act: Carrying the Ukraine team placard during the opening ceremony of the Milan Cortina Winter Games.

Kucherova was swathed in a long, hooded silver puffer coat, her eyes covered with dark glasses ‚Äî like all the other placard bearers for the 92 nations competing in the Olympics. The Ukraine sign was illuminated for the crowd to read.

At first the country assignments were going to be random, but later the choreographer asked if the volunteers had preferences, and Kucherova chose Ukraine.

Kucherova, an architect who has been living in Milan for 14 years, was unrecognizable, and her nationality was not announced to the public when she led the five Ukrainian athletes competing in Milan into San Siro stadium to resounding cheers.

She first revealed her role to her 879 Instagram followers and then in an interview with The Associated Press.

‚ÄúWhen you walk by the side of these people you realize they have every human right to feel hatred towards any Russian,‚Äô‚Äô she told the AP on Monday. ‚ÄúStill, I think it‚Äôs important to do even a small action to show them that maybe not all the people are thinking the same way."

For Kucherova, speaking about her small act of resistance on the second anniversary of the poisoning death of dissident Alexei Navalny is a way of reminding the world that the war continues, even as life elsewhere goes on.

‚ÄúUkrainians don‚Äôt have any possibility to avoid these thoughts or to ignore the existence of war. So it is their reality. They keep loving each other, getting married or doing sports, coming to the Olympics. But all of this is happening (against) a devastating background.‚Äù

Without being told that Kucherova was Russian, the athletes immediately recognized her origins and addressed her in Russian. That was a sign for Kucherova of ‚Äúsome profound connection‚Äù between Russians and Ukrainians ‚Äúthat obviously could live on if not for the war.‚Äù

The Milan delegation was led by flag bearer Yelyzaveta Sydorko, a short track speedskater, and included figure skater Kyrylo Marsak. Both athletes have fathers who are fighting on the front lines in a war that is nearing its fourth anniversary.

‚ÄúThere is literally no word you can say that can undo the harm that these people have already suffered, and there is no word that can come in close to forgiveness,‚Äô‚Äô said Kucherova.

Right before walking into the stadium, ‚ÄúI turned around ‚Äî I didn‚Äôt know what to say to them ‚Äî but I just said that the entire stadium is going to give them the standing ovation.‚Äô‚Äô The Ukrainians appeared skeptical, she said.

When the cheers came, Kucherova said it felt like the entire stadium was ‚Äúrecognizing their independence, recognizing their will for freedom, their courage in making it all the way to the Olympics.‚Äù

She cried, silently, behind her glasses.

Kucherova hasn't visited Russia since 2018, but understands that she is taking a risk by defying the regime.

‚ÄúI have to be worried about this, and I‚Äôm supposed to be scared about this. And I cannot guarantee that me speaking out will not harm any people I know,‚Äô‚Äô she said. ‚ÄúBut what I think is that if I, living in a democratic country and enjoying all the freedoms, if I am scared, this means that the regime has won.‚Äù

Kucherova held the sign for another delegation, Denmark, which also received a rousing ovation for that nation's resistance of U.S. threats to take over Greenland, a self-governing Danish territory.

‚ÄúYes, this is a coincidence, but I pondered over it,‚Äù Kucherova said.

AP Winter Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/milan-cortina-2026-winter-olympics

title: Raiders‚Äô Klint Kubiak making strategic moves to win over Maxx Crosby
description: Las Vegas Raiders coach Klint Kubiak does not want to lose defensive end Maxx Crosby in his first stint with the team.
fullText:
Raiders‚Äô Klint Kubiak making strategic moves to win over Maxx Crosby appeared first on ClutchPoints. 

The Las Vegas Raiders are facing another offseason filled with uncertainties despite the hiring of coach Klint Kubiak. Arguably, the biggest question is: Will Maxx Crosby remain with the Silver and Black?

Crosby has been at the center of trade rumors following another atrocious campaign by the Raiders, which saw them win only three games and miss the playoffs for the fourth straight season.

At this point, the star defensive end‚Äôs future in Las Vegas is teetering. But according to Sports Illustrated‚Äôs Albert Breer, Kubiak is making strategic moves to entice the five-time Pro Bowler to stay.

‚ÄúKlint Kubiak comes in, and one of the first things he does is he goes and gets a cup of coffee the other morning with Maxx Crosby. My understanding is that the breakfast went really well, that there was a good rapport between Klint Kubiak and Maxx Crosby. But that nothing really materially changed,‚Äù said Breer on his show.

‚ÄúNow, since then, Kubiak has decided to name Rob Leonard, who was the defensive line coach and the run team coordinator last year, Maxx Crosby‚Äôs position coach, the new defensive coordinator of the Raiders. So could that move the needle? We‚Äôll see.‚Äù

In March, the Raiders signed the 28-year-old Crosby to a three‚Äëyear extension worth $106.5, making him the highest‚Äëpaid non‚Äëquarterback in league history, further underscoring his importance to the team.

Yet a season later, the relationship between the team and its cornerstone defender appears to have frayed. For a guy as competitive as Crosby, being on a losing team must be extremely frustrating. He, however, has also discussed the importance of loyalty, stating that he wants to build something with the Raiders.

While Crosby has largely dismissed the trade rumors, Kubiak, who replaced Pete Carroll, should not be complacent and ensure that the two-time All-Pro will stay in Sin City.

title: Duke Lays Waste To Syracuse, 101-64
description: This one started as an interesting game and ended as an absolute tour de force for the Blue Devils.
fullText:
Syracuse kept up with Duke for about the first 11 1/2 minutes but after that it was all Duke in a 101-64 blowout.

For the first few minutes, Syracuse did play well and to their credit they competed hard throughout. But Duke was just much, much better in this one.

Cameron Boozer had a double-double ‚Äì in the first half. And arguably, he was the second-best player for Duke in that half, behind Isaiah Evans.

Duke dominated in nearly every facet. Although the Blue Devils started slow from outside, that changed as the game went on. And they dominated around the basket despite William Kyle‚Äôs best efforts at controlling the lane.

Boozer and Evans were particularly difficult for Syracuse to control. Boozer finished with 22 points and 12 rebounds while Evans racked up 21.

Evans in particular showed a lot of growth and toughness. He‚Äôs a long way from the three-point specialist he was as a freshman. He drove the lane, he faked, he muscled around the basket. It was a really solid performance on his part.

You know who else was incredibly impressive? Dame Sarr.

That guy is turning into an unbelievable defender. He‚Äôs been so aggressive that the crowd is actually oohing and aahhing over how he‚Äôs just smothering guys on defense. It‚Äôs pretty unusual to see someone who is that quick on defense and he‚Äôs 6-7. When he‚Äôs on, what can you do? He‚Äôs emerging as a devastating defender.

Pat Ngongba has had some erratic performances this year, notably at Louisville and UNC. Not this time.

Ngongba finished with 12 points and 7 rebounds and was aggressive inside without getting into foul trouble.

Caleb Foster didn‚Äôt score much ‚Äì just one three ‚Äì but he ran the team well. He also had no turnovers. Here‚Äôs an incredibly impressive stat, by the way: Duke had just 4 turnovers all game.

Maliq Brown, Nik Khamenia and Cayden Boozer were all great off the bench. Brown did his usual things ‚Äì defending guys in ways they could never expect and scoring and passing efficiently. He finished with 6 points and 5 assists and several surprises for the Orange.

As for Khamenia, this was a really good game from him. He finished with 14 points on 5-7/3-3 from the floor and played with immense confidence, which was great to see. In his last few games he‚Äôs seemed to lack that at times. He was a huge factor.

He‚Äôs emerged as a steady player and one who tends to make particularly smart plays in winning time. Those won‚Äôt always show up in a box score, but they still count. He gets those plays right an amazing number of times.

Check out his stat line here: 12 points on 5-6/2-3 from the floor, with 1 rebound, 4 assists, 0 turnovers and 3 steals.

In the end, Syracuse played hard and never quit, but the lead just kept growing. Soon after the half, it swelled past 20, then past 25 and ultimately to 37 by the end.

There‚Äôs just not a lot to pick over here. Could Duke have been better at the line? Yeah, that might be a problem in a tighter game. The Blue Devils shot just 13-20 (65%). However, of those 7 misses, Sarr missed all 4 of his attempts, which skews things a bit.

In general, this game was a Cameron thrill ride, especially in the second half. Everyone played well and more importantly, played well together.

Now it‚Äôs on to Michigan Saturday, and that game is going to be really interesting and a great stress test for both teams.

Notes ‚Äì William Kyle also missed all four of his free throw attempts and he may have the ugliest form we‚Äôve ever seen‚Ä¶he‚Äôs tall and athletic but other than blocking shots and dunking, he hasn‚Äôt leveraged it much‚Ä¶Cameron Sheffield got in late and got a three and a rebound‚Ä¶Duke‚Äôs bigs got 9 assists between them‚Ä¶Cooper Flagg, Kon Knueppel and Khaman Maluach were all in attendance, as was Steve Wojciechowski, among other former Blue Devils‚Ä¶Syracuse is now 15-12 and a 37-point loss will cause more hot-seat talk for Adrian Autry‚Ä¶Nate Kingz had a tough childhood‚Ä¶he‚Äôs an easy guy to pull for and we hope he keeps rising‚Ä¶JJ Starling shot just 3-13‚Ä¶Duke and Sarr harassed Naithan George into 4 turnovers‚Ä¶

title: Estelline/Hendricks wins fourth straight gymnastics title
description: MITCHELL, S.D. (KELO) ‚Äî The class ‚ÄòA‚Äô state gymnastics meet was held on Friday in Mitchell. The race for the crown came down to just a few points as a familiar name continued its dominant run. The Redhawks entered Friday‚Äôs team competition as the three-time defending state champs.
fullText:
MITCHELL, S.D. (KELO) ‚Äî The class ‚ÄòA‚Äô state gymnastics meet was held on Friday in Mitchell. The race for the crown came down to just a few points as a familiar name continued its dominant run.

The Redhawks entered Friday‚Äôs team competition as the three-time defending state champs. That placed a target on their back, but the team was able to fight through the pressure.

‚ÄúOur team was just rallied behind each other and having a good time. We were doing our things and hitting our routines,‚Äù Johnson said. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs all we could ask for.‚Äù

Estelline/Hendricks claimed a fourth straight title, edging out Parkston/Ethan/Hanson/Mt. Vernon by less than three points.

‚ÄúVery relieved, very happy and very proud of our team. We had a lot of injuries and it was very hard for everybody to forget about that and work as hard as we can, but we did,‚Äù Hausman said.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm feeling so excited. We did a lot of hard work and it‚Äôs just so relieving to get here,‚Äù Hartung said.

Sherri Johnson is in her eighth year as the Estelline/Hendricks head coach. She says all seasons are special, but this one will standout.

‚ÄúJust the adversity that we went through and just to call on some kids that had to step up,‚Äù Johnson said. ‚ÄúIt was a whole team effort to get there. It gave me chills, and I had tears my eyes.‚Äù

The Redhawks have 20 athletes on their roster, 15 of which are freshman or younger, but that‚Äôs one of Coach Johnson‚Äôs favorite parts of the sport.

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs the great thing that I love about gymnastics is you get them in seventh grade and you get to keep them until 12th,‚Äù Johnson said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre a family and they‚Äôre like your own daughters.‚Äù

The Redhawks found success in the individual competiton on Saturday. Hausman claimed first place, while Hartung earned third.

title: Arizona Cardinals QB Jacoby Brissett 2026 offseason profile
description: A look at quarterback Jacoby Brissett's season, his contract and what to expect in the offseason.
fullText:
The 2026 league year is coming next month. It officially begins on March 11, with the legal negotiating period beginning on March 9.

The Arizona Cardinals have many roster decisions to make before then.

Leading up to the new league year, we will profile every player on the roster, go over what they did last season, what their contract status is and what they face in 2026.

Next up is quarterback Jacoby Brissett.

Brissett joined the Cardinals on a two-year contract last offseason to be Kyler Murray's backup.

He ended up being the Cardinals' No. 1 quarterback after Murray's foot injury. He started 12 games, went 1-11 and 0-9 in the final nine games, but he had a career year.

He completed 64.9% of his passes for 3,366 yards, 23 touchdowns and eight interceptions. He set career-highs in passing yards and touchdown passes.

Brissett is signed through 2026. He will make $4.9 million salary and a $2 million bonus. He will count nearly $9.2 million against the salary cap.

While the biggest question of the offseason is about Kyler Murray, another very important question is what the Cardinals expect from Brissett in 2026? Will he enter the season as the starter after going 1-11 as a starter and not playing well in any high-leverage situation? Will he be happy returning to a backup role? Does new head coach Mike LaFleur want him?

Brissett might actually have the better trade value between him and Murray because Brissett's contract is very reasonable, especially if a team needs someone who can start.

Get more Cardinals and NFL coverage from Cards Wire's Jess Root and others by listening to the latest on the Rise Up, See Red podcast. Subscribe on Spotify,¬†YouTube¬†or¬†Apple podcasts.

This article originally appeared on Cards Wire: Jacoby Brissett's contract status and 2026 offseason outlook

title: Nico Williams: United joined by fierce rivals in blockbuster transfer race
description: Manchester United are reportedly exploring a possible summer move for Athletic Club winger Nico Williams.According to a report from TeamTalk, United have already held talks regarding the Spain interna...
fullText:
Manchester United are reportedly exploring a possible summer move for Athletic Club winger Nico Williams.

According to a report from TeamTalk, United have already held talks regarding the Spain international.

The update suggests that the 23-year-old‚Äôs name is being discussed as the club looks ahead to potential attacking additions for the next transfer window.

The situation is seen as a major opportunity, with Williams described as a forward who could add a new dynamic in wide areas.

The same report references a valuation of ¬£87m, underlining the scale of any deal should United decide to move beyond initial contacts.

Williams has long been linked with Premier League clubs, and he is positioned as a high-upside target.

Wayne Rooney has previously been unequivocal about the winger‚Äôs ceiling, comparing his style to Cristiano Ronaldo‚Äôs early years.

The former United striker wrote: ‚ÄúWilliams, for me, is exceptional. He reminds me of Cristiano Ronaldo when Cristiano was young.‚Äù

Rooney added: ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a big lad, he‚Äôll take the ball and sometimes tries too much but usually makes the right decisions.‚Äù

He continued: ‚ÄúHe is an incredible threat in one-on-one situations and scores goals as well.‚Äù

While recruitment planning intensifies behind the scenes, United‚Äôs immediate focus remains on a return to Premier League action at the Hill Dickinson Stadium when they face Everton away on Monday, 23 February.

With the season entering a decisive stretch, it remains to be seen whether the report develops into a formal approach.

For now, the latest claim simply places Williams on the list of wide forwards being discussed, with Rooney‚Äôs Ronaldo comparison serving as a reminder of the level United would be aiming to add.

The Peoples Person has been one of the world‚Äôs leading Man United news sites for over a decade. bsky.social

title: What's next for Tyreek Hill after his release from the Dolphins? Keep an eye on Chiefs and Bills
description: Tyreek Hill is now a free agent for the first time in his career.
fullText:
Tyreek Hill is officially a free agent, putting him in an unfamiliar position for the first time in his career.

So, what‚Äôs next for the star wide receiver?

The Miami Dolphins officially released Hill on Monday, ending a four-season run in which the franchise bet big on him being a key piece to pair with quarterback Tua Tagovailoa. Ultimately, that didn‚Äôt work out. The Dolphins failed to win a single playoff game during his time in South Florida, continuing a drought that dates back to the 2000 season.

Hill went down with a devastating knee injury early this past season, too, including a dislocated knee. Hill‚Äôs agent said Monday that he‚Äôs ‚Äúprogressing well‚Äù in his rehab and will be ready to play at some point next season, and Hill vowed to return.

But who is in play for Hill next season? Yahoo Sports‚Äô ‚ÄúInside Coverage‚Äù podcast discussed a couple of possibilities Monday.

"He still has that speed. Even if he's 80% of what he was, he's still going to be one of the faster players in the NFL," Yahoo Sports senior betting analyst Ben Fawkes said. "So I think he can be a useful piece for a contender, but also at what price is the big question too."

The first landing spot is obvious. The Chiefs are the easiest match for Hill because his career began in Kansas City, and he won a Super Bowl ring there. He appeared to give a nod of approval on social media of the Chiefs' recent re-hiring of Eric Bieniemy as offensive coordinator.

But Hill‚Äôs usage in Kansas City may not be what he‚Äôs used to.

"Is [Hill] willing to accept a lesser role if that's what he is right now? Let's say the Chiefs, right? Well, is he their No. 1 [wideout]? No, that's probably Rasheed Rice, who has his own set of baggage,‚Äù Yahoo Sports NFL senior reporter Frank Schwab said. ‚ÄúAnd is he their speed guy? Well, no, that's probably Xavier Worthy. What role is he willing to accept? How much money is he willing to accept?"

There are, naturally, a lot of questions to be answered there. But Hill would be a solid weapon for the Chiefs, who just missed the playoffs for the first time in more than a decade.

Buffalo appears hellbent on doing just about anything possible to help lift quarterback Josh Allen over the postseason hump and to a Super Bowl. That included jettisoning a successful head coach in Sean McDermott in favor of offensive coordinator Joe Brady earlier this offseason.

Hill could be an easy add for a team needing an extra option. Khalil Shakir was their leading receiver last year with just 719 receiving yards, while tight ends Dalton Kincaid and Dawson Knox were second and third.

"They need that veteran piece," podcast host Andrew Siciliano. "They need that deep threat. They need a guy who down the field ‚Äî I'm sorry, Brandin Cooks ‚Äî can attack that football or just run away from the guy closest to him. So he doesn't have to have a contested catch there to win a playoff game in Denver."

The Chargers could be a great fit for Hill for multiple reasons. He‚Äôd get to pair up with Justin Herbert, who has statistically been a top tier quarterback during his first six seasons in the league even if the team has struggled at times. The Chargers have plenty of money to pay Hill, too, as they‚Äôre sitting with the third-most salary cap space in the league this offseason.

Oh, and Mike McDaniel is now the Chargers‚Äô offensive coordinator after he was fired by the Dolphins earlier this offseason. Reuniting with his former head coach on the other side of the country feels like it would make things even easier for Hill coming off of his injury.

Sure, the Patriots reached Super Bowl LX this past season. But something was missing, and that was very evident in the final game as the Seahawks cruised to the dominant win in the Bay Area.

Hill could easily step into New England and help young quarterback Drake Maye as he enters his third season in the league. Pairing Hill with fellow star Stefon Diggs, who racked up 1,013 receiving yards last season, and tight end Hunter Henry, might just be the boost the team needs to get over the hump.

Now this may not be Hill's first choice, considering the state of the Raiders in recent years. But there are plenty of reasons why it would work.

The Raiders are under new leadership once again this season with Klint Kubiak coming in as their head coach. The franchise has the No. 1 overall pick in the NFL Draft, too, which they will presumably use on Indiana quarterback and Heisman Trophy winner Fernando Mendoza. Getting Mendoza a veteran like Hill right away in his career, along with young running back Ashton Jeanty and tight end Brock Bowers, would be huge early on in his career.

Oh, and the Raiders have money to spend. That'd be nice for Hill, too.

title: 'Dodgy burger' rules Santner out against Canada as New Zealand targets T20 World Cup Super 8s
description: Canada won the toss Tuesday and elected to bat against a New Zealand lineup targeting a spot in the Super 8s at the T20 World Cup.  Stand-in captain Daryl Mitchell said regular skipper Mitchell Santner is sick and will miss the game because he ‚Äúhad a dodgy burger last night.‚Äù  Cole McConchie replaced Santner as a like-for-like replacement in the XI.
fullText:
CHENNAI, India (AP) ‚Äî Canada won the toss Tuesday and elected to bat against a New Zealand lineup targeting a spot in the Super 8s at the T20 World Cup.

Stand-in captain Daryl Mitchell said regular skipper Mitchell Santner is sick and will miss the game because he ‚Äúhad a dodgy burger last night.‚Äù

Cole McConchie replaced Santner as a like-for-like replacement in the XI.

New Zealand was forced into another change with Kyle Jamieson coming in for pace bowler Lockie Ferguson, who returned home for the birth of his first child. Ferguson is scheduled to rejoin the team during the Super 8s.

A third win in Group D would seal New Zealand‚Äôs place in the next round alongside South Africa, England, West Indies, India and Sri Lanka. New Zealand started the tournament with victories against Afghanistan and United Arab Emirates before losing to South Africa.

Canada has never played a T20 international against New Zealand. But in the one-day international format, the Black Cups have won all three previous matches against Canada.

Canada is last in the group following losses to United Arab Emirates and South Africa and will be knocked out of the tournament if it loses to New Zealand.

Later Tuesday, Zimbabwe is aiming for a win over Ireland that would also knock 2021 champion Australia out in the first round of the tournament for the first time since 2009. Nepal, which has lost all its three group games, is rounding out its T20 World Cup campaign against Scotland.

Canada: Yuvraj Samra, Dilpreet Bajwa (captain), Navneet Dhaliwal, Harsh Thaker, Nicholas Kirton, Shreyas Movva, Saad Bin Zafar, Shivam Sharma, Dilon Heyliger, Jaskaran Singh, Ansh Patel.

New Zealand: Tim Seifert, Finn Allen, Rachin Ravindra, Glenn Phillips, Mark Chapman, Daryl Mitchell (captain), Cole McConchie, James Neesham, Kyle Jamieson, Matt Henry, Jacob Duffy.

AP cricket: https://apnews.com/hub/cricket

title: ‚ÄúMy understanding‚Äù ‚Äì Fabrizio Romano doubles down on Chelsea transfer news
description: Transfer expert Fabrizio Romano has doubled down on some Chelsea transfer news regarding striker Nicolas Jackson.The Blues player is currently on loan at Bayern Munich for the season, but it has becom...
fullText:
Transfer expert Fabrizio Romano has doubled down on some Chelsea transfer news regarding striker Nicolas Jackson.

The Blues player is currently on loan at Bayern Munich for the season, but it has become pretty clear that they will not be signing him in the summer when his loan deal runs out, and he will return back to Chelsea.

But does that mean he now has a chance of coming back into the Chelsea squad and in the thinking of new manager Liam Rosenior? Well, anything can happen in this game, but Romano still doesn‚Äôt think Jackson will, despite reports from Germany yesterday suggesting that Jackson could now move forward and stay with Chelsea into next season and beyond.

Romano was always adamant that Jackson was leaving Chelsea before the summer of 2025 and that there was no way he would be staying at the club. So this paints the picture that his Chelsea story is over, and now he‚Äôs doubling down on that.

Nicolas Jackson playing for Bayern. (Photo by Adam Pretty/Getty Images)

In words cited on X last night, Romano said on Nicolas Jackson:

‚ÄúRemember Chelsea already signed a striker for the summer, [Emmanuel] Emegha, who is similar in terms of skills to Jackson, so that‚Äôs a point. Of course a change of manager means a possibility [Nicolas] Jackson stays, but my understanding is that it‚Äôs expected that different opportunities on the market will be explored, rather than staying.‚Äù

Chelsea tried to stop his loan move to Bayern when Liam Delap got injured but the striker point blankly refused to come back. It would SHOCK me if they could all move forward together now!

title: LeBron James Admits To Wanting To Visit China ‚ÄúAt Some Point‚Äù
description: China is a huge market for the NBA, and that is nothing new. Among the league‚Äôs international audiences, few countries can go toe to toe with the second-most populous nation in the world.
fullText:
China is a huge market for the NBA, and that is nothing new. Among the league‚Äôs international audiences, few countries can go toe to toe with the second-most populous nation in the world. Because of that, the NBA makes sure to establish its presence on the ground every single year. The face of the league, LeBron James, understands this as well.

James has been to China 15 times so far for his Nike promo tour. It‚Äôs also not been that long since his last visit, with the King traveling to China as recently as 2025 to promote his ‚ÄúForever King‚Äù tour, to promote his LeBron 23 shoes. Was it also a farewell visit? One last visit to China?

Not according to James, who, during media availability at All-Star Weekend, admitted that he would like to make another trip to the East.

‚ÄúTo all my fans and people over there it‚Äôs always been great,‚Äù James stated. ‚ÄúAlways welcomed me and my friends and family in open arms. I‚Äôve always appreciated it, they‚Äôre be another opportunity for me to go over there at some point.‚Äù

James has remained coy on his relationship with China over the years. He found himself in hot water in 2019 when he went against Daryl Morey‚Äôs statement on China.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want to get in a word or sentence feud with Daryl Morey, but I believe he wasn‚Äôt educated on the situation at hand, and he spoke.‚Äù

Since then James has returned to China on a semi-regular basis as he did before the incident as well. So, it‚Äôs safe to say he‚Äôs welcome in the country to quite a fair extent.

Even if James retires from the NBA after the 2025-26 season, as some believe he will, Nike, which has supported him throughout his career, would still look to capitalize on his popularity in China. Both James and the iconic American brand remain hugely popular there, despite the political tensions between the two countries.

At the same time, it looks as though James has another country in his mind he would love to visit. And that‚Äôs Israel.

In the same presser in L.A., James was asked about his thoughts on the Middle-Eastern country, and his reply showed that he really wanted to go there. ‚ÄúIf I have fans over there ‚Äî I‚Äôve never been there ‚Äî I hope you follow my career, I hope I inspire people over there.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot only to be great in sports, but to be better in general in life, hopefully someday I can make it over there,‚Äù the Lakers icon added. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve heard great things and I appreciate the question.‚Äù

For now, though, James cannot travel anywhere that far from home. Crunch time in the season is here with the All-Star break nearly over, and his focus is solely on possibly ending his career with a fifth ring.

The post LeBron James Admits To Wanting To Visit China ‚ÄúAt Some Point‚Äù appeared first on The SportsRush.

title: For Sunderland, Radical Changes Post-Speakman Could Be Hazardous
description: ‚ÄúI really do hope that moving forward, the void that Kristjaan Speakman leaves won‚Äôt lead to instability‚Äù.
fullText:
If the confirmation and timing of Kristjaan Speakman‚Äôs Sunderland departure took many people by surprise when it was confirmed on Friday afternoon, the only thing more worthy of animated discussion than his legacy at Sunderland was what his exit might lead to ‚Äî as well as the precedent the departure of such a notable figure in our recent history might set.

Did he get everything right during his five-year spell at the Stadium of Light? Of course not.

Did he occasionally make decisions on recruitment which were unpopular and sometimes misguided, as well as leaving people frustrated at his public statements? Yes.

Did the end ‚Äî that of gaining a place in the Premier League ‚Äî justify the means? Without a doubt, and for what it‚Äôs worth, I always felt his comments in the media were lost to print as in reality, he‚Äôs a calm, measured and effective speaker ‚Äî something I certainly noticed during his appearance at a fan forum following the appointment of R√©gis Le Bris.

Time will be very kind to Speakman‚Äôs legacy on Wearside but with Florent Ghisolfi now at the helm and a key component of our recent structure gone, it‚Äôll be a new version of Sunderland AFC that tackles the remainder of the campaign and Le Bris may find himself being judged by a different set of standards as a result ‚Äî something I do feel could potentially be hazardous.

I really do hope that moving forward, the void that Speakman leaves won‚Äôt lead to instability, a lack of forward planning and the kind of uncertainty that we need to avoid at any and all costs. Much has been made of the ambition of Kyril Louis-Dreyfus and his willingness to make bold calls in order to ensure continued progress, but I also think a note of caution should be sounded.

‚ÄúRuthlessness‚Äù ‚Äî however it may manifest itself ‚Äî in footballing circles is often dangerous and as we see with some of the frankly cartoonish dismissals and panicked appointments made in the Premier League, flexing your muscles as an owner (occasionally to rectify a mistake that should never have been made) can be riddled with potential pitfalls.

Taking what often appeared to be a cold, iron-clad approach to hiring and firing might‚Äôve worked for Chelsea when Roman Abramovich‚Äôs rubles were keeping the Blues on the leading edge of dominance, but we‚Äôre different ‚Äî or we should be ‚Äî and I would hate to think that Speakman‚Äôs departure heralds the dawn of a scattergun approach that ultimately leads to the kind of turbulence that we‚Äôve tried to escape from.

Barring a cataclysmic end to the season, Le Bris‚Äô position ought to be as safe as houses.

He‚Äôs been one of the most important Sunderland head coaching appointments of my lifetime. He‚Äôs helped to create a sense of togetherness that we‚Äôve seldom seen and has propelled us forward rapidly, and his calm, measured and unflappable personality is a perfect fit for our club.

Yes, we may have a little bit of work to do in the league and to realign the balance from defensive-minded football to a more positive approach, but let nobody be any doubt that 2025/2026 has the potential to be a memorable season for Sunderland, and our head coach has been as key to that as any of his players.

Perhaps I‚Äôm something of a lone voice here, but as much as I‚Äôd sell a kidney in order to see Sunderland competing in Europe and the like, I‚Äôm not in a rush. I‚Äôve experienced enough highs and lows in thirty years of red and white fandom and I can honestly say that I can‚Äôt understand the desperation in some circles to see certain boxes ticked by a certain time or date.

Here and now, I‚Äôm happy for the club to be a stable and competitive top flight outfit and to hopefully develop a style of play that can eventually enable us to compete in the upper reaches of the table. I firmly believe Le Bris can be the man to oversee that process and I would only advocate a change in the dugout if a genuine upgrade appeared on the club‚Äôs radar ‚Äî which is by no means guaranteed.

For everyone ‚Äî fans and owner alike ‚Äî patience and planning are the watchwords and just as Le Bris said that we wouldn‚Äôt play like other teams because ‚ÄúWe are Sunderland and I am R√©gis Le Bris‚Äù, perhaps a similar mindset: ‚ÄúWe won‚Äôt manage our personnel like Watford or Nottingham Forest‚Äù, should be adopted by those in the boardroom.

For our long-term stability and top flight prospects, it would surely be a smart thing to do.

title: Lasses Spotlight: Ella West ‚Äî The Quiet Rise Of A Sunderland Talent
description: ‚ÄúWest‚Äôs journey this season has been a lesson in resilience‚Äù, writes Charlotte Patterson of the young defender.
fullText:
There are players whose progress feels inevitable, even when circumstances conspire to slow their momentum.

Ella West is one of them, and her call‚Äëup to the Scotland U19 squad for their upcoming double‚Äëheader against Belgium is more than a line on a squad announcement graphic. Instead, it‚Äôs a statement, a reminder, and confirmation that the talent Sunderland have long known they possess is still very much recognised beyond Wearside ‚Äî even after a season that‚Äôs been shaped more by recovery than by rhythm.

For Sunderland supporters, the news carries a mixture of pride and relief.

Pride because her ability has never been in doubt; relief because this season has offered far fewer opportunities to see her in red and white than anyone would‚Äôve hoped. Injuries have a way of interrupting even the most promising trajectories, and West‚Äôs campaign has been defined by the kind of stop‚Äëstart pattern that frustrates players and fans alike.

Yet here she is, selected for her country and trusted to represent Scotland at a level where competition is fierce and standards uncompromising. It‚Äôs testament to her quality, her resilience and the impression she‚Äôs already made on coaches at both club and international level.

West‚Äôs story this season isn‚Äôt one of failure or stagnation ‚Äî it‚Äôs one of patience.

She‚Äôs spent much of the year working her way back to fitness, rebuilding her sharpness and waiting for the moment when her body would allow her to show what her mind has always known she can do. For a young player, that kind of enforced pause can be difficult as the game moves quickly and opportunities come and go, yet she‚Äôs handled it with maturity and her Scotland call‚Äëup is the clearest sign yet that her development hasn‚Äôt been derailed, merely delayed.

What makes her selection even more impressive is the context of her role at Sunderland. She‚Äôs predominantly a PGA player and part of the club‚Äôs development pathway, but she isn‚Äôt a stranger to senior football.

Last season, she earned starts and minutes with the first team, stepping into the then-Championship environment with a composure that belied her age. Whether deployed in her natural position at centre back or pushed into central midfield, she showed the same qualities: intelligence, calmness and an ability to read the game that marks her out as a player with a high ceiling.

Those senior minutes mattered, showing that she could cope with the physicality, the tempo, and the tactical demands of the league. They proved that she wasn‚Äôt simply a promising academy player, but someone capable of contributing in real matches and under real pressure. And they showed that Sunderland‚Äôs long‚Äëterm plan for her, to integrate her gradually into the senior squad wasn‚Äôt just aspirational, but achievable.

This season, injuries have slowed that process and Sunderland have had to manage her carefully, ensuring that her recovery is prioritised over short‚Äëterm needs.

It‚Äôs meant fewer appearances, fewer opportunities and fewer moments for supporters to see her progress. But the club never wavered in their belief in her. They know what she brings, what she‚Äôll become, and that her route back to the senior squad is there.

Her call‚Äëup to the Scotland U19s is a significant step in that journey. International football ‚Äî even at youth level ‚Äî demands a level of concentration and tactical discipline that accelerates development. It exposes players to different styles, different challenges, and different expectations.

For West, who‚Äôs spent much of the season rebuilding physically, the chance to test herself in this environment is invaluable. It gives her minutes, confidence and momentum at a time when she needs all three.

It also offers something more subtle: validation.

For a young player recovering from injury, confidence can be fragile. You can train well, feel sharp and pass every fitness test, but until someone selects you and says, ‚ÄúWe trust you‚Äù, there‚Äôs always lingering doubt. Scotland have removed that doubt, showing that they still see her as part of their plans, that they believe in her potential and still want her involved. That kind of affirmation can transform a player‚Äôs mindset.

For Sunderland, the timing couldn‚Äôt be better.

The senior squad has been stretched this season, and the defensive unit in particular has faced its share of challenges. The team have lacked depth at centre back at times, but West‚Äôs ability to cover ground, read danger early and to play out from the back with composure makes her a natural fit for the way Sunderland want to build.

She‚Äôs not just a defender who clears her lines ‚Äî she starts attacks, and her experience in central midfield only adds to her value.

It‚Äôs given her a broader understanding of the pitch, a better sense of timing and a confidence in possession that many centre halves her age don‚Äôt possess. It also means she can step into the midfield lines when needed, helping Sunderland maintain structure in transitions and offering an extra layer of control when the team are under pressure. That versatility is rare and it‚Äôs one of the reasons the club sees her as a long‚Äëterm asset.

Once she returns from Scotland duty, the expectation is that she will rejoin senior training more consistently.

The coaching staff have been cautious but they‚Äôve also been clear: West is part of their plans. They want her involved, competing and pushing for a place on the bench again. And once she‚Äôs back on the bench, the next step becomes inevitable: minutes. Real minutes. Not token appearances, but meaningful involvement in matches where Sunderland need fresh legs, fresh ideas and fresh energy.

Supporters haven‚Äôt forgotten what she offered last season.

They remember the calmness, the maturity and the way she slotted into the back line without fuss. They also remember the glimpses of a player who could become a mainstay in years to come, and they know that Sunderland‚Äôs identity ‚Äî built on developing young talent, trusting their pathway and on giving opportunities to players who come through the system ‚Äî is strengthened every time someone like West takes the next step.

Her return will not solve every issue Sunderland have faced this season, but it‚Äôll help, adding depth, competition and a sense of renewal at a moment when the squad needs it. It‚Äôll also remind everyone that the club‚Äôs future isn‚Äôt just about the players who start every week, but about the players who are being shaped, nurtured and prepared to take on bigger roles.

West‚Äôs journey this season has been a lesson in resilience.

Injuries test more than the body; they test belief, patience and the ability to stay focused when the game moves on without you. She‚Äôa passed that test by staying committed, engaged and ready. And now, with her Scotland call‚Äëup, she‚Äôs been rewarded.

The next chapter is hers to write and it won‚Äôt be long before she‚Äôs training with the senior squad, competing for a place on the bench and pushing for minutes. And if her development continues on its current trajectory, it‚Äôs only a matter of time before those minutes become more frequent, meaningful, and more reflective of the talent she possesses.

For now, though, she heads to Belgium with her country. Fit again. Trusted again. Recognised again. And ready to remind everyone ‚Äî Sunderland, Scotland and herself ‚Äî of the player she‚Äôs becoming.

title: Nostalgic Win At Oxford: A Reminder of Sunderland‚Äôs Journey!
description: ‚ÄúA tussle with a familiar opponent was the palate-cleanser I think we all needed after a run of difficult games‚Äù.
fullText:
Being a Sunderland fan is a funny thing.

One minute you‚Äôre seemingly teetering on the edge of unholy disaster, then, poof ‚Äî it can all change in an instant. You‚Äôre getting promoted, you‚Äôre winning games, and you‚Äôre on a cup run.

Just as quickly as things can ramp up, stuff goes awry and it‚Äôs that constant rollercoaster ride that makes Sunderland such a compelling football club ‚Äî and why companies like Netflix invested money and time in documenting how batshit mental we are over a number of years.

Still, it‚Äôs fair to say that right now, things are about as good as they‚Äôve even been in my lifetime, and whilst the demon on my right shoulder keeps telling me that this will all go tits up eventually, I‚Äôm pleasantly surprised by how well we seem to be staying the course right now in the Premier League.

Trips to Anfield and Old Trafford are great, but there was something hopelessly nostalgic about Sunderland‚Äôs trip to Oxford on Sunday. It was warm, comfortable and familiar. We‚Äôve been treated to some big games against big opponents with big-name players over the last six months or so, but a shithouse tussle with a familiar opponent at the weekend was the palate cleanser I think that we all needed after a run of difficult and demanding games in the top flight.

I love Luke O‚ÄôNien and Dennis Cirkin, so any opportunity that I get to see them run it back for us is a huge positive. And in both cases, they gave classic performances that reminded me of the days we spent in the EFL, going toe-to-toe with some absolute cloggers that on their day can scare and upset you if you don‚Äôt want it quite as much as they do.

Don‚Äôt get me wrong ‚Äî I absolutely love Reinildo Mandava and Omar Alderete, and it‚Äôs been an absolute joy (for the most part) to see them in a Sunderland shirt this season, but players like O‚ÄôNien and Cirkin are the real reasons that I fell back in love with Sunderland all over again after an immensely mentally scarring period under some seriously shitty ownership and management.

They came along during the club‚Äôs worst ever period, and have survived to tell the tale. They ‚Äî and we ‚Äî are living proof that it doesn‚Äôt matter how bad things are, your club will eventually come out of the other side much stronger and better off for it. Sheffield Wednesday and Leicester fans, take note.

Of course, I‚Äôm absolutely buzzing for the game on Sunday and I can‚Äôt wait to be there to cheer the Lads on, but that doesn‚Äôt make the feeling of seeing the likes of O‚ÄôNien playing and playing well any less sweet.

I know Luke has a personal love/hate relationship with this here website, but he‚Äôs always been a Sunderland legend to me and I just absolutely adore him. He‚Äôs my favourite ever Sunderland player and I get genuine, serious pleasure from watching him play as well as he did on Sunday. It‚Äôll be a sad day when he eventually leaves, so I‚Äôll hold days like that dearly close to my heart and hope that there are still many more to come.

I hated the EFL but I can‚Äôt deny that it brought us many happy memories too, and it brought players like Luke, Dennis, Dan Ballard and Trai Hume into our lives, and for that I‚Äôm thankful.

Sunday was a reminder of the journey we‚Äôve been on, passing through places like Oxford with players like Luke in our team.

Where are we headed from here? Who knows, though the trajectory of the club would suggest that there will be far fewer trips to places like Oxford, and perhaps far more trips to places that we possibly have never been before.

title: How NASCAR Team Owners and Drivers Supported Tyler Reddick After His Son‚Äôs Unfortunate Health Condition
description: Tyler Reddick and his family went through a tough time in the latter half of 2025. The Cup Series driver‚Äôs infant son, Rookie, had to undergo surgery to remove a kidney after he was diagnosed with a tumor that was increasing the stress on his heart.
fullText:
Tyler Reddick and his family went through a tough time in the latter half of 2025. The Cup Series driver‚Äôs infant son, Rookie, had to undergo surgery to remove a kidney after he was diagnosed with a tumor that was increasing the stress on his heart. In an interview after he won the Daytona 500 on Sunday, he detailed how the NASCAR community helped him in those days.

Rookie was born on May 25, 2025. It was around late September when doctors at the Atrium Health Levine Children‚Äôs Hospital in Charlotte confirmed that he had a tumor in his chest and that it was compressing his renal artery and vein. This was causing his heart to work heavier than normal, and it was why he was showing signs of heart failure.

Any parent in this situation would be terrified, and Reddick was too. Fortunately, he received some able support from his friends. He said, ‚ÄúMichael and everybody at 23XI Racing basically told me, ‚ÄòLook. If you need to step away and not run another race‚Ä¶ do whatever you need to do.‚Äô Just having everyone‚Äôs support along the way was incredible.‚Äù

The support wasn‚Äôt limited to his team. He continued, ‚ÄúWhen my wife was headed down there, Rick Hendrick and his whole group were doing everything they could to kind of expedite the process for Rookie. Joey Logano, a fellow competitor of mine, was reaching out, doing everything he could to pick up Beau and let him go hang out with Joey‚Äôs kids while we were dealing with that.‚Äù

He quipped that the amount of support he got from the NASCAR community throughout the whole deal was incredible. At the end of the day, all that matters is that the boy is safe and is recovering well. The cherry on top of the cake is that Rookie actually began crawling for the first time during the Daytona 500 weekend.

Reddick was jubilant about that as well. To win the Harley J. Earl trophy and to celebrate it with his family after undergoing such scary battles must be a memorable moment for him. The season has just begun under the Chase format, and he has kicked off on the best foot possible.

But winning the championship will require consistency at this same level throughout the year. Reddick is only too capable of producing that. Without question, Rookie, too, wouldn‚Äôt mind visiting more Victory Lanes with his father.

The post How NASCAR Team Owners and Drivers Supported Tyler Reddick After His Son‚Äôs Unfortunate Health Condition appeared first on The SportsRush.

title: Does USA hockey play today? Schedule, time, channel for next United States Olympic men's hockey game
description: The USA men's hockey team is off to the quarterfinals. Here's what you need to know about their next game.
fullText:
Does USA hockey play today? Schedule, time, channel for next United States Olympic men's hockey game originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The United States conquered Group C in men's hockey, winning all three games and securing a bye to the quarterfinals.

While the USA didn't look quite as dominant as Canada and ceded the No. 1 seed to their neighbors to the north, the real competition is about to begin. The U.S. can win gold with three consecutive wins, though a loaded Canada team could certainly stand in the way.

As the bracket portion of the Olympic hockey tournament gets underway, Team USA is hoping the best is yet to come.

Here's what you need to know about the United States' next game and the full schedule for Olympic men's hockey.

The USA does not play on Tuesday, as they received a bye to the quarterfinals of the men's hockey tournament.

Tuesday's slate features four games involving teams that finished between seeds 5-12. The top four seeds advanced directly to the quarterfinals, and the United States earned the bye by securing the No. 2 seed.

Here are the details on Team USA's next game.

The United States will play its next game on Wednesday, Feb. 18, with puck drop set for 3:10 p.m. ET. The USA will face the winner of Tuesday's playoff matchup between No. 7 Sweden and No. 10 Latvia, with Sweden the decisive favorite in that game.

The game will air nationally on NBC and can streamed live on¬†Peacock.

Sweden could pose an unusually strong threat to the U.S. for a No. 7 seed. The Swedes entered the Olympics with the third-shortest odds to win gold, and their roster is loaded with NHL talent. After appearing less sharp than expected at times during the preliminary round, though, that kind of challenge could benefit the United States in the long run.

MORE:Complete Olympic men's hockey bracket

The bracket portion of the Olympic men's hockey tournament begins on Tuesday, followed by all four quarterfinal matchups on Wednesday.

title: Jude Bellingham: Real Madrid star will join United on one condition
description: Manchester United‚Äôs hierarchy‚Äôs two biggest priorities ahead of next season are to find a permanent manager and strengthen their midfield.On Monday, Jurgen Klopp‚Äôs agent, Marc Kosicke, claimed t...
fullText:
Manchester United‚Äôs hierarchy‚Äôs two biggest priorities ahead of next season are to find a permanent manager and strengthen their midfield.

On Monday, Jurgen Klopp‚Äôs agent, Marc Kosicke, claimed that the former Liverpool boss turned down approaches from United and Chelsea following his departure from Anfield.

It has been widely reported that Real Madrid are interested in hiring Klopp, who is currently Head of Global Soccer for Red Bull. United might have failed in their bid to convince Klopp, but his next potential move could fix their second concern: the midfield.

According to a report in Spain, as relayed by Football365, Jude Bellingham has ‚Äúagreed in principle‚Äù to join Manchester United in the summer if Real Madrid secure the services of Jurgen Klopp.

It has been a rough season for Los Blancos and Bellingham. Early this season, Real Madrid sacked Xabi Alonso and placed Alvaro Arbeloa in charge of the first team.

At the time, it was suggested that there was a rift between Bellingham, who is enduring an injury-laden campaign, and Alonso. Now, it is being claimed that the Englishman would not be part of Klopp‚Äôs plans if the German were to accept the Spanish giants‚Äô job offer.

It is claimed that Bellingham ‚Äúhas a deal in place to leave Real Madrid if Jurgen Klopp takes over as manager.‚Äù

The England international has ‚Äúreached an agreement in principle with Manchester United to facilitate an immediate departure should a change in management occur.‚Äù

The report adds: ‚ÄúThe move is contingent solely on Klopp‚Äôs arrival. If the German coach does not land at the Santiago Bernab√©u, the midfielder intends to remain at the club.‚Äù

Bellingham allegedly prefers to ‚Äúget ahead of the curve‚Äù and find a club where he would be handed a prominent role.

It is understood United are prepared to offer him that status and build their project around him.

Former United manager Ole Gunnar Solskjaer tried to sign Bellingham after he broke through at Birmingham City. Eventually, the 22-year-old chose Borussia Dortmund before sealing a ‚Ç¨103 million move to Real, where he has already lifted the Champions League trophy.

There are question marks over Bellingham‚Äôs attitude, but as far as on-field quality is concerned, there are only a few midfielders better than the Real Madrid superstar.

Featured image Angel Martinez via Getty Images

title: On This Day (17th Feb 1976): The Joy Of Sunderland: Did They ‚ÄòStoke‚Äô Your Passion?
description: A classic Roker Park atmosphere and a lively cup tie was sure to get the fire burning for legions of Lads‚Äô fans!
fullText:
A wonderfully evocative article from Barry Jackson has prompted today‚Äôs feature, which looks at a game that brought the romance of the FA Cup back to Wearside just as his new love affair with Sunderland was blossoming.

The Lads‚Äô battling fifth round showing in Staffordshire forced a replay and despite Stoke City‚Äôs top flight status, the rematch at Roker Park seemed to be firmly in the balance.

Our strong home record would eventually see us finish the season as Division Two champions, and when added to their notorious cup pedigree, it gave many supporters the sense that an upset was on the cards ‚Äî although as it happened, large sections were anything but comfortable for the hosts.

Manager Bob Stokoe, whose main concern prior to kick off was a flu bug that was starting to spread through the club, had to watch on as his team were put through a tough examination by the Potters. As it was, only Billy Hughes and Ian Porterfield ‚Äî two men who‚Äôll have recalled a similar issue when the FA Cup was won earlier in the decade but had since fallen out of first team contention ‚Äî were the only players laid up, yet those able to take to the pitch found the going tough.

Well-structured Stoke had plenty of the ball, although they didn‚Äôt always turn possession into clear-cut chances, and it was Sunderland that looked the more dangerous actually when they did get the opportunity to push forward.

Having seen a thirty-fifth minute Pop Robson strike ruled out for offside, Bob Moncur and Mel Holden also went close before a finely-poised chess battle ensued, with Stokoe‚Äôs decision to opt for a back five giving the Rokerites the ability to stem the flow of pressure their higher division opponents were looking to build on.

The massed crowd, which had given the club their biggest attendance of the season thus far, was beginning to sense that things could go either way but rather than add to the tension, they began to turn the volume up.

A wall of noise began to swirl around the stadium and when the final fifteen minutes brought about an intense period of drama, the atmosphere was right up there in terms of classic Roker nights. A superb near post header from Holden as he connected with a Bobby Kerr corner was greeted by jubilant scenes on the terraces, and whilst Denis Smith soon replied for Stoke, the fans didn‚Äôt waver once.

Smith ‚Äî who in time would himself get to enjoy the backing of the red and white army when he became manager on Wearside ‚Äî registered an instant leveller when a free kick found its way onto the post and he was on hand to poke it over the line, yet the scruffy nature of the equaliser meant Sunderland were able to maintain the belief that they were good enough to win, as rather than being outdone by a moment of skill, they‚Äôd instead been pegged back through a touch of misfortune.

Kerr, who was awesome throughout, soon set about Stokoe‚Äôs left hand side and when his centre was half-cleared, the ball was put back into the area by Dick Malone.

It was a wonderfully weighted cross and one that Robson was able to control and flick into the net (albeit via a deflection), to spark further celebrations in the jam-packed Fulwell End behind the net.

Despite owing something to luck just as the goal that had proceeded it, the winner felt fully deserved.

In Robson, the Lads had a finisher every bit as good as Stoke‚Äôs usual First Division adversaries, whilst behind him was a level of energy and determination that any successful side needs ‚Äì a feeling summed up moments before the goals when Jimmy Robertson put a late tackle in on Tony Towers and the skipper was more than happy to give a bit back.

Following the clash, Robertson was booked whilst Towers got let off with a stern telling-off from referee Mr T.H.C Reynolds, but the message was clear: Sunderland were up for the cup.

With a place in the quarter finals now confirmed, murmurings of a potential remarkable double soon got traction.

However, the push went to pot when a niggly sixth round encounter with Crystal Palace turned Sunderland into the victims of a giant-killing and with all the attention quickly reverting to the promotion chase, this match can now sometimes be overlooked when recounting the big post-war cup ties staged at Roker.

Still, there‚Äôll be some for whom the memories still exist ‚Äî and maybe even be one or two who pinpoint the replay as the day their own Sunderland relationship began.

Barry‚Äôs origin story is shared by many and although the locations and the characters might change, the essence is the same: love at first sight that leads to a passionate tale that spans a many great years.

Sunderland versus Stoke in 1976 might be less heralded that when Manchester City were the opponents at the same stage three years earlier, for instance, but it‚Äôll be no less important to somebody that fell head over heels.

Sunderland 2 (Holden 77‚Äô, Robson 81‚Äô)
